titleStmt.title: Prayers of warre for the kingdome, iudgment and iustice which God hath promised to execute under heaven here on earth, for to maintaine his word (or holy name) and to deliver this people. Against the rage and fury of the horrible and pernitious beast, which devoureth and breaketh in peeces, and stampeth the residue with its feete, blasphemeth God the most High, and endevoreth to change times and lawes. Daniel. 7. Whereunto is added an earnest voyce or letter to the late Roman emperour. Written and set forth first in the German tongue by one, who through many dangers a long time undantedly hath in person denounced unto the Roman emperour and many kings, princes and states, the iudgement of God over the world, and the deliverance of Israel, and still doth continue to admonish all people of the same.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 26 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 9 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 112743)

titleStmt.title: Prayers of warre for the kingdome, iudgment and iustice which God hath promised to execute under heaven here on earth, for to maintaine his word (or holy name) and to deliver this people. Against the rage and fury of the horrible and pernitious beast, which devoureth and breaketh in peeces, and stampeth the residue with its feete, blasphemeth God the most High, and endevoreth to change times and lawes. Daniel. 7. Whereunto is added an earnest voyce or letter to the late Roman emperour. Written and set forth first in the German tongue by one, who through many dangers a long time undantedly hath in person denounced unto the Roman emperour and many kings, princes and states, the iudgement of God over the world, and the deliverance of Israel, and still doth continue to admonish all people of the same.

notesStmt.note: Reproductions of the originals in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-05 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2011-03 Simon CharlesText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: PRAYERS OF WARRE FOR THE KINGDOME, Iudgment and Iu≈øtice which God hath promi≈øed to execute under Heaven here on Earth, for to maintaine his WORD (or HOLY NAME) and to deliver his people. Again≈øt the Rage and Fury of the Horrible and pernitious Bea≈øt, which devoureth and breaketh in peeces, and ≈øtampeth the re≈øidue with its feete, bla≈øphemeth God the Mo≈øt High, and endevoreth to change Times and Lawes. Daniel. 7. Whereunto is added an earne≈øt voyce or Letter to the late Roman Emperour.

Written and ≈øet forth fir≈øt in the German Tongue by one, who through many dangers a long time undantedly hath in per≈øon denounced unto the Roman Emperour, and many Kings, Princes and States, the Iudgement of God over the world, and the deliverance of I≈ørael, and ≈øtill doth continue to admoni≈øh all people of the ≈øame.
London Printed for G. Thomp≈øon. 1642.

div.head: PRAYERS OF WARRE For the Kingdome, Iudgment and Iu≈øtice, which God hath promi≈øed to execute under Heaven here on Earth, for to maintaine his Word (or Holy Name) and to deliver his People.
div.p: 1. GOD THE FATHER, who hath of Nothing Created Heaven, Earth, the Seas and All that therein is, by the hand of his Divine and Almighty power, have pitty, and deliver the Creature of his hands, through the Grace, Vertue and Strength of his Divine Iu≈øtice, from the power of the Kingdome of Eternall Darkne≈ø≈øe.

2. O LORD JESVS CHRIST, Thou onely Begotten Sonne of God, and Saviour of all tho≈øe that truely beleeve in Thee, Thou Eternall King and Prince of Victorie, by whom Sinne, Death, Devill and Hell is overcome and de≈øtroyed: Have pitie, and deliver tho≈øe People from the Might and Power of all thine and their Enemies, which Thou ha≈øt redeemed with thy mo≈øt Holy and Precious Blood, and exceding dearely bought to thy Everla≈øting Kingdome.

3. GOD THE HOLY GHOST, Thou Divine Fire, which art the burning flame, light, vertue and ≈øtrength of all beleevers, kindle and revive thy members with the vertue
of thy Strength, that they through the power of God may bee pre≈øerved to eternall Salvation,

Thou Holy Trinitie, God the ‚Ä¢ ather, God the Sonne, and God the Holy Gho≈øt, in One Eternall, Divine and Vndivi≈øible E≈ø≈øence, performe and fulfill what thou ha≈øt promi≈øed, concerning the maintaining of thy Word and Holy Name, and the deliverance of thy People, and ha≈øt in thy Eternall Coun≈øell decreed and e≈øtabli≈øhed again≈øt the rage and furie of the Devill and all his members.

For there is none like unto thee O Lord, thou art great, and thy Name is great, and thou can≈øt ≈øhew it in the very Deede; who ≈øhould not feare thee, O King of Nations: To thee Obedience is due, fora≈ømuch as among all the wi≈øe men of the Nations, and in all their Kingdomes, there is none like unto thee: Thou Lord art the true God, and the living God, an everla≈øting King, at thy wrath the Earth trembleth, and the Nations cannot abide thine indignation. The Gods that have not made the Heavens and the Earth, even they mu≈øt peri≈øh from the earth, and from under the Heavens. But thou ha≈øt made the Earth by thy power, and e≈øtabli≈øhed the world by thy Wi≈øedome, and ha≈øt ≈øtretched out the heavens by thine Vnder≈øtanding, When thou uttere≈øt thy voyce, there is a multitude of Waters in the Heavens. Ier. 10.
Thou Lord mo≈øt high art very terrible, a great King over all the Earth, thou reigne≈øt over the Heathen, thou ≈øitte≈øt upon the Throne of thine Holine≈ø≈øe. P≈øal. 47.

The Heathens mu≈øt de≈øpaire, the Kingdomes fall, the earth mu≈øt peri≈øh when he uttereth his voyce; he that maketh Wars to cea≈øe unto the end of the Earth, that breaketh the Bow, and cutteth the ≈øpeare in ≈øunder; that burneth the Chariot in the Fire. P≈øal. 46.

Thou breake≈øt the ≈øhips of Thar≈øis with an Ea≈øt winde; as wee have heard ≈øo have wee ≈øeene in the Citty of the Lord of Ho≈øts, in the City of our God: God will e≈øtabli≈øh it for ever, Selah. God we waite for thy loving kindne≈ø≈øe in thy Temple.
According to thy Name, O God, ≈øo is thy prai≈øe unto the ends of the Earth. Thy Right-hand is full of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, P≈øal 48.

Let the Heavens rejoyce, and let the Earth be glad, let the Sea roare and the fulne≈ø≈øe thereof, let the Field be joyfull and all that is therein, and let all the Trees of the Wood rejoyce before the Lord, for hee commeth, hee commeth to Iudge the earth; he ≈øhall Iudge the World with righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and the People with his Truth. P≈øal. 96.
Hee bowed the Heavens and came downe, and darkene≈ø≈øe was under his feete. P≈øal. 18.

A fire goeth before him and burneth up his Enemies round about; his Lightning enlightens the World; the Earth ≈øeeth it and trembleth, the Hills melt like waxe at the pre≈øence of the Lord, at the Pre≈øence of the Lord of the whole Earth. The Heavens declare his Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and all people ≈øee his Glory. P≈øal. 97.
For the Lord ≈øhall Iudge and avenge his People, and have pittie upon his Servants. Deut. 32.

In Salem is his Tabernacle, and his dwelling place in Sion: there breaketh he the Arrowes of the Bow, the ≈øhield and the Sword and the Battell, Sela. Thou art more glorious and excellent then the Mountaines of prey, the ≈øtout harted mu≈øt bee ≈øpoyled, and ≈øleepe their ≈øleepe, and the Warrious mu≈øt let their hands ≈øinck, at thy rebuke O God of Iacob, both the chariot and the hor≈øe are ca≈øt into a dead ≈øleepe; Thou, even thou art to bee feared, and who may ≈øtand in thy ≈øight when once thou art angry, when thou cau≈øe≈øt the Iudgement to bee heard from Heaven then the Earth feareth and is ≈øtill, P≈øalme 76.
For, thou O Lord art a Iealous God, and a Revenger, yea a revenger is the Lord and furious; The Lord will take vengeance on his adver≈øaries, and he re≈øerveth wrath for his Enemies, Nahum. 1.

Thou covere≈øt thy ≈øelfe with Light, thou ≈øtretche≈øt out the
Heavens like a Curtaine, thou laye≈øt the beames of thy chambers in the Waters, thou make≈øt the clouds thy Charet, thou walke≈øt upon the wings of the Winde. P≈øalm. 104.

Thou art the Lord, Who≈øe wayes are in the whirle-winde and in the ≈øtorme, and the clouds are the du≈øt of thy feet; thou that rebuke≈øt the Sea and make≈øt it dry, and drye≈øt up all the Rivers: the Mountaines quake at Thee, and the Hills melt: the Earth quaketh at thy pre≈øence, yea the world and all that dwell therein; who can ≈øtand before thine Indignation, and who can abide in the fiercene≈ø≈øe of thine anger; thy furie burneth like fire, and the Rocks are throwne downe by him. Nehemiah. 1.

Thou looke≈øt on the Earth and it trembleth, thou touche≈øt the Hills and they ≈ømoake: the earth trembleth and is moved, and the foundations of the Mountaines are moved and doe tremble, when thou art angrie. P≈øal. 104.

Smoake goeth up out of thy No≈øtrills, and a con≈øuming fire out of thy Mouth, whereby coales are kindled: thy Pavillion round about thee is darke, and darke thick cloudes wherein thou art hidden: at the brightne≈ø≈øe before Thee the Clouds pa≈ø≈øe with Haile and lightnings, and the Lord thundred in the Heavens, and the highe≈øt gave his voice with Haile and coales of fire: He ≈øent out his arrowes and ≈øcattered them, he ≈øhort out lightnings and di≈øcomfited them. P≈øal. 18.

Who is ≈øo great a God as Thou O God, thou art the God that doe≈øt wonders; thou ha≈øt declared thy ≈øtrength among≈øt the People; thou ha≈øt powerfully redeemed thy people, the ≈øonnes of Iacob, and Io≈øeph Sela. The waters ≈øaw Thee, O God, the water ≈øaw thee and were afraid, the depths were troubled, the thick cloudes powred out Water, the clouds did thunder, and thy arrowes went abroad: thy lightnings lightned the world, and the Earth trembled and ≈øhooke. P≈øal. 77.
Great is our Lord, and of great Power, his vnder≈øtanding is infinite. P≈øal. 147.

What≈øoever he plea≈øeth that he doth in Heaven and in
Earth, in the ≈øeas and in all deepe places, that cau≈øeth the Vapours (and cloudes) to a≈øcend from the endes of the Earth, that maketh lightnings to raine, that bringeth the windes out of his Trea≈øures. P≈øal. 135.

Who covereth the Heavens with cloudes, who prepareth raine for the Earth, who maketh gra≈ø≈øe to grow upon the Mountaines: he giveth Snow like wooll, he ≈øcattereth the Hoare fro≈øt like a≈øhes; He ca≈øteth forth his Ice like mor≈øels; who can ≈øtand before his Cold? He ≈øendeth out his word and melteth them, He cau≈øeth his Winde to blow and it thawes, P≈øal. 147.
By the Word of the Lord the Heavens were made, and all the Ho≈øt of them by the breath of His Mouth. P≈øal. 33.
For who in the Clouds may be compared unto the Lord, who among the Sonnes of the Gods can bee likened unto the Lord. P≈øal. 89.
There is none like unto the God of Ie≈øurun, (or of the righteous) who rideth upon the Heaven, who≈øe excellencie is in the Skie, and vnderneath are the everla≈øting armes Deut. 33.
Who executeth Vengance in anger, and fury upon the Heathen, that would not hearken. Mich. 5.

For the Lord is a great God and a great King above all Gods; in his hand are the deepe places of the Earth, and the hights of the Hills are his, for the Sea is his, and he made it, and his Hands formed the dry land. P≈øal. 95.

The Lord is great, and greatly to be prai≈øed, he is to be feared above all Gods: Honour and Maje≈øty are before him; ≈øtrength and beauty are in his Sanctuarie. Let the Heavens rejoyce, and let the Earth be glad, let the Sea roare and the fulne≈ø≈øe thereof, let the Feild be ioyfull, and all that is therein, and let all the Trees of the Wood reioyce. P≈øal. 96.
Make a Ioyfull Noi≈øe unto the Lord, all the Earth, ≈øerve the Lord with gladne≈ø≈øe: come before his pre≈øence with ≈øinging, Know yee that the Lord he is God. P≈øal. 100.
For thou Lord, art high above all the Earth, thou art exalted farre above all Gods. P≈ø. 97.

The Flouds lift up, O Lord, the flouds lift up their Voyce, the flouds lift up their Waves: The Lord on high is mightier then the Noi≈øe of many Waters, yea then the mighty waves of the Sea. P≈øal. 93.
Therefore will not we feare, though the Earth be removed, and though the mountaines ≈øhould ≈øinck in the mid≈øt of the Sea. P≈øal. 46.
For thou ≈øtille≈øt the Noy≈øe of the Seas, the noy≈øe of the waves, and the tumult of the people, P≈øal. 65.

Why doe the Heathen rage, and the people imagine a vaine thing: the Kings of the Earth ri≈øe up, and the Rulers take Coun≈øell together, again≈øt the Lord and again≈øt his Anointed; therefore ≈øhall his wrath ≈øoone bee kindled P≈øal. 2.
The Indignation of the Lord is upon all Nations, and his Fury upon all their Armies, E≈øa. 34.
His Anger burneth, and is very heavie: His lips are full of indignation, and his Tongue as a devouring fire, and his breath as an overflowing ≈øtreame, E≈øa. 30.
Our God ≈øhall come and ≈øhall not keepe ≈øilence, a fire ≈øhall devoure afore him, and it ≈øhall be very tempe≈øtuous round about him P≈øal. 50.
Hee ≈øhall let burning Coales fall upon his enemies, and hee ≈øhall with fire throw them downe into deepe pitts, that they never ri≈øe up againe. P≈øal. 140.
Behold he commeth ≈øaith the Lord of Ho≈øts, but who may abide the Day of his Comming? and who ≈øhall ≈øtand when he appeareth? Malach. 3.

Deur. 4. 6. 9. & 32. ch. Heb. 1 ‚Ä¢ . and 12. ch. P≈øal. 103. E≈øa. 45. Deut. 10. Exod. 15.For He is a Iealous God, and a con≈øuming fire, that ≈øhall devoure all the earth with the fire of his Iealou≈øie, Zephan. 1. & 3. chap.
Therefore bow the Heavens, O Lord, and come downe, touch the Mountaines that they ≈ømoake, ca≈øt forth Lightning and ≈øcatter them, ≈øhoot out thine arrowes and de≈øtroy them, P≈øal. 144.
P≈øal. 103. E≈øa. 45. Deut. 10. Exod. 15.For thou Lord of Hoa≈øts art the onely God, the God of all Gods, and the Lord of all Lords; terrible, worthie to be prai≈øed, and doing wonders.
Thou ha≈øt a Mighty arme, ≈øtrong is thy hand, and high is thy right hand. P≈øal. 89.
Thy righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe is like the great mountaines: Thy Iudgements are great deapths. P≈øal. 36.
Surely the wrath of Man ≈øhall prai≈øe Thee, the remainder of wrath ≈øhalt thou re≈øtraine, P≈øal. 76.

Great is the Lord, and greatly to bee prai≈øed, and his greatne≈ø≈øe is un≈øearchable: his Kingdome is an everla≈øting kingdome, and his Dominion endureth throughout all generations. Dan. 2. and 4. P≈øal. 145.

The Lord bringth the Coun≈øell of the Heathen to nought, he maketh the devi≈øes of the people of none effect, but the Coun≈øell of the Lord ≈øtandeth forever: the thoughts of his heart to all generations. P≈øal. 33. E≈øa. 8. & 13.

Make a joyfull noy≈øe unto the Lord al the earth: Make a loud noy≈øe, and rejoyce, and ≈øing prai≈øe: ≈øing unto the Lord with the Harpe, and the Voice of a P≈øalme, with Trumpets and ≈øound of Cornet, make a ioyfull noy≈øe before the Lord, the King. Let the Sea roare, & the fulnes thereof: the world & they that dwell therin: Let the flouds clap their hands, let the hills bee ioyfull together before the Lord, for he commeth to iudge the Earth, with righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øhall he iudge the World, and the people with equity. P≈øal. 98.

There is no King ≈øaved by the Multitude of an Hoa≈øt: a mighty man is not delivered by much ≈øtrength; a hor≈øe is a vaine thing for ≈øafety, neither ≈øhall he deliver any by his great ≈øtrength. P≈øal. 33.

O Lord God of Ho≈øts, who is a ≈øtrong Lord like unto thee? Thy truth is round about thee, Thou rule≈øt the raging of the Sea; when the waves therof ari≈øe, thou ≈øtille≈øt them: thou breake≈øt Rahab in peeces as one that is ≈ølaine, Thou ≈øcattere≈øt thine Enemies with thy ≈øtrong Arme. p≈øal. 89.

Thou devide≈øt the Sea by thy ≈øtrength, Thou breake≈øt the Head of the Dragons in the waters: thou breake≈øt the heads of Leviathan in pieces, and give≈øt them to be meate to the people inhabiting the wilderne≈ø≈øe; thou cleave≈øt the fountaine and the floud, thou drye≈øt up mighty Rivers: The Day thine, the Night al≈øo: thou prepare≈øt the Light & the Sun, thou ≈øette≈øt all the Borders of the Earth, thou make≈øt Summer and Winter P≈øal. 74.

The Heavens are thine, the Earth al≈øo is thine: as for the World and the fulne≈ø≈øe thereof, thou ha≈øt found them; the North and the South, thou ha≈øt created them: Tabor and Hermon ≈øhall reioyce in thy Name, P≈øal. 89.
Ble≈ø≈øed is the Nation, who≈øe God is the Lord, and the people whom he hath cho≈øen for his owne inheritanc, P≈øal. 33.
God thy Worke is Holy, un≈øearchable & incomprehen≈øible are the Iudgements. P≈øal. 77. Rom. 11.
Thou ha≈øt prepared thy throne in the Heavens, and thy Kingdome ruleth over All. P≈øal. 103.

Thou make≈øt thine Angells windes, thy Mini≈øters a flaming fire, who laid≈øt the foundations of the earth that it ≈øhould not be removed for ever: ever: Thou covered≈øt it with the Deepe as with a garment: The waters ≈øtood above the Mountaines: at thy rebuke they fled: at the Voyce of thy Thunder they ha≈øted away. P≈øal. 104.

Eccle. 43. E≈øa. 2. 3. 40. 50. chap.The noy≈øe of his Thunder maketh the Earth tremble, & the Mountaines quake before him, for the Glory of his Maje≈øtie, and for the Voyce of his Glory ≈øhall, the Mountaines depart, and the Hills be remoued. Rev. 6.

The Voyce of the Lord is upon the waters, the God of Glory thundreth, the Lord is upon many Waters; the Voyce of the Lord is very powerfull; the voyce of the Lord is full of Maje≈øty: the voyce of the Lord breaketh the Cedars, yea the Lord breaketh the Cedars of Lebanon; the Voyce of the Lord divideth the flames of Fire: the voyce of the Lord ≈øhaketh the wilderne≈ø≈øe; the Lord ≈øhaketh the wilderne≈ø≈øe of Cades, the Lord ≈øitteth upon the floud, yea the Lord ≈øitteth King for ever: The Lord will give ≈øtrength unto his people: the Lord will ble≈ø≈øe his People with peace, P≈øal. 29.

For he is the Lord ≈øtrong and Mighty, the Lord mighty in battell. Lift up your Heads O you gates, even l ‚Ä¢ ft them up ye everla≈øting doores, and the King of Glory ≈øhall come in. Who is the King of Glory, the Lord of Ho≈øts, he is the King of Glorie, Sela. P≈øal. 24.

He ≈øhall Iudge the ends of the earth, and hee ≈øhall give ≈øtrength unto his King, & exalt the horne of his Anoynted: But the Adver≈øaries of the Lord ≈øhall bee broken in peeces, out of Heaven ≈øhall the thunder open them. 1. Sam. 2.
Vpon the wicked he ≈øhall raine Snares, fire and brim≈øtone, and an horrible Tempe≈øt; this ≈øhall be the portion of their Cup. P≈øal. 11.

Hee ≈øhall let burning coales fall upon his enemies, he ≈øhall let them be ca≈øt into the fire, into the
deepe pitts, that they ri≈øe not up againe. P≈øal. 40.
Heb. 1 & 7. P≈øal. 45. 97. Mich. 4. 5. 7 chap.O God, thy Throne is for ever and ever, the Scepter of thy Davidicall Kingdome is a Scepter of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. P≈øal. 89. 110. 145.

Prai≈øe ye the Lord, pray≈øe the Lord O ye Heavens; prai≈øe Him in the Hights; Prai≈øe ye Him all His Angells: Prai≈øe ye him all His Hoa≈øts: Prai≈øe ye Him Sunne and Moone, prai≈øe Him all ye Sarres of Light: Prai≈øe Him yee Heavens of Heavens, and ye Waters that be above the Heavens: Let them prai≈øe the Name of the Lord; for He commanded and they were Created. He hath al≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed them for ever and ever. He hath made a Decree which ≈øhall not pa≈ø≈øe. Prai≈øe the Lord from the Earth, ye Dragons and all deepes, Fire and Haile, Snow & Vapour, Stormy Winde fulfilling His Word, Mountaines and all Hilles: fruitfull Trees and all Cedars. Bea≈øts & Cattell: Creeping things and flying fowle. P≈øal. 148.

Ble≈ø≈øe the Lord yee His Angels that excell in ≈øtrength, that doe His Commandements, harckning unto the Voyce of His WORD. Ble≈ø≈øe yee the Lord all ye his Ho≈øts, yee Mini≈øters of His that doe his plea≈øure.
Ble≈ø≈øe ye the Lord all His Workes in all places of His Dominion: ble≈ø≈øe the Lord O my ≈øoule. P≈øal. 103.
Prai≈øe and Glory and Wi≈øedome, and Thankes, and Honour, and Power, and Might bee unto Our God for ever more Amen. Revel. 7.

closer.signed: A Warriour from God, ACcording to His Grace, Truth and Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, which God hath promi≈øed to keepe unto David and his Seede after Him for ever, (to wit) ≈øo long as the Ordinance with Heaven and Earth, Sunne & Moone, Day and Night endureth.Revel. 10. P≈øal. 89. 2 Sam. 7. 1 King. 2. 6. 8. 9. 2 Chron. 6. 7. chap. Ier. 30. 31. 33. chap. Mich. 7.

div.head: A VOYCE or Letter which denounceth Gods Vengeance and Iudgement to the Emperour and his Adherents.
E≈øa. 30. A Voyce, By which the Lord of Ho≈øts out of Sion warneth thus.
div.p: Ierem. 25. Ioel 3. Amos 1. Deut. 1 & 10 E≈øa. 2 & 3. 1 Pet. 1. Eccl. 1. 10. 35. Rom. 2. 14. 4 E≈ød. 11. 12. Sap. 6. P≈øal. 36. 58. Revel. 16.It needeth not many di≈øputes or proofes to ≈øhew that the Ruler is no more e≈øteemed in the eyes of the Maje≈øtie of God the mo≈øt High; (by whom there is no re≈øpect of Per≈øons, 2 Chron. 19. Gal. 2. Eph. 6. Col. 3.) then he that is under the rule.

Neither are further Demon≈øtrations nece≈ø≈øary to prove that the Emperour, (who is the Horne or Temporall Head of that Terrible and hurtfull Bea≈øt, which breaketh all in peeces, and ≈øtampeth the re≈øidue with its feete, Dan. 7.) neither regardeth nor hath regarded either the Lawes of God or of Nature, to conforme his Government thereunto, according to Con≈øcience, but by the Power of Satan domineereth directly again≈øt them, upon the Throne of God.

Gen. 4. Num. 23. 24. Heb. 11.The Blood of the oppre≈ø≈øed, and the Violence u≈øed again≈øt tho≈øe that ≈øuffer, hath long enough
cryed to Heaven to the Eternall God. Revel. 6. Deut. 32. Deut. 17. Mich. 5.Who therefore is ri≈øen again≈øt the Emperour and his Adherents, to bring to nought in them, all the plots and devices of the Devill, which they have devi≈øed again≈øt God, His Word and believers. E≈øa. 4. 14. 15. 35. 49. Chap. Zephan. 3.

Ioel 3. Nah. 3. 1 Iohn 3. Rom. 1. 6. Sap. 6. P≈øal. 2. 76. 137. 2 The≈ø. 2. E≈øa. 51. & 5. 4. chap.And becau≈øe tho≈øe that ≈øerve him, have not only no lawfull calling, but ≈øubmitt them≈øelves al≈øo to the Devill, when they ri≈øe and lift up them≈øelves again≈øt God, & torment poore men here upon his Earth, by no other then by the power and workeing of the very Devill: They have rea≈øon to looke well about them, and con≈øider how their Ma≈øter will be able to helpe them when they have ≈øerved again≈øt God. Zach. 2. 12. 14. Ierem. 30.

Revel. 13. Deu. 7. 12. E≈øa. 61. 63. 2 The≈ø. 1. Sap. 5.Seeing the Emperour, who in poore and afflicted Mankind lifts him≈øelf up again≈øt God, both in a Coporall and Spirituall manner, is not able to helpe and deliver him≈øelfe from the day of the Vengeance and Iudgement of God, much le≈ø≈øe to a≈ø≈øi≈øt tho≈øe that helpe him, or doe de≈øire to fulfill his diabolicall devices and enterpri≈øes. Hab. 1. P≈øal. 137. E≈øa. 31. 49. 52. 59.
Sap. 18. Mat. 24. Out of Midnight, OR

Mala. 4. 2 Cor. 4. Gen. 49. Gen. 49. Revel. 5. 22. E≈øa. 4. 8. 11. 28. 42. 59. 66. Mal. 4.IN the mid≈øt of the Night, when Faith is extingui≈øhed, Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sunne of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øet, yea no light more is within the Hearts and Con≈øciences of men, Zach. 4.) Commeth the Lion of the Tribe of Iuda, E≈øa. 65. Heb. 7. 10. The roote of David, by whom God the great Lord, for the maintenance of the Honour of His
Word or Holy Name, Eze. 35. 36. and the full Deliverance of Mankind will make him≈øelfe knowne among≈øt the unbelieving and ungodly Heathen. Rom. 1. and 11. chap. Hypocrites, Scorners and De≈øpi≈øers, Epi≈øt of Iude; or fal≈øe and titular Chri≈øtians. Tit. 1. Mat. 24. Mar. 13. 2. Pet. 3.

4 E≈ødr. 11. 12. E≈øa. 47. 52. Revel. 10. 17. 18. 19. 20. 21. chap.Men ≈øhall fall upon thy feathered Wings, O Thou Eagle, and thy clawes and feathers, Kingdome and governement, namly they whole Body or adherents, ≈øhall in the DAY of the LORD and IVDGEMENT OF GOD, utterly be de≈øtroyed from under the Heavens, Ierem. 10. 25. Dan. 7.

E≈øa. 66. Revel. 20. 2 Pet. 3. Mich. 5. 6. & 7. chap. Revel. 2. P≈øal. 49. 96. 97. 98. 99.The Contents of this VOYCE have binn in≈øinuated to the late decea≈øed Emperour many yeares agoe, who for his doings undoubtedly is now under Gods Iudgement and in the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, Revel. 17. For God will not ≈øuffer His Holy Name to bee defiled, nor his people forced again≈øt their Soules and Con≈øciences: therefore this Letter or Earne≈øt Voice, Concerning the Iudgment of God is now againe publi≈øhed, that no man a≈ø≈øi≈øt another in his unju≈øt cau≈øe again≈øt God His Faithfull, and ≈øo bring them both into Hell. But they that will e≈øcape the Fiery Lake in regard of the≈øe pre≈øent tumults, they mu≈øt in all their actions, 2 Cor. 5. not onely outwardly in the Eyes of Men, P≈øal. 14. but al≈øo in their hearts, not goe again≈øt God. Rom. 9. 1 Pet. 2.4. Who tryeth the hearts and reynes, Ier. 11. 17. and looketh into the ≈øecrets of Men, E≈øa. 29. Ierem. 23. according to which He will al≈øo Iudge, 1 Cor. 4. Ier. 30. Ezech. 34. 37.

closer.signed: Dan. 12. Revel. 12. & 20. 2 The≈ø. 1.A WARRIER according to the Truth and Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of God & His Iudgement, Crowned with afflictions and Sufferings, armed with Faith, Hope and Patience, Heb. 10. Which is in our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. 1 The≈ø. 1.
